>> All right. So, what we're looking at
here is a construction phasing schedule.
This would represents one page of maybe
like a dozen pages of very specific
phases of a project that the client
might might want to see being built in
our animation. So, each row represents a
specific phase with specific dates for
what components need to be shown or
removed or like added to the project or
removed. This traditionally has been
very very difficult for us because these
schedules change all the time. So once
we build out an animation in 3ds Max,
changing even just one component of that
can cause like a cascading effect where
every other piece of our animation also
has to be either removed or offset and
sometimes it was just easier just to
completely start over. So we knew that
we had to have some way of automating
this in a real. So this is our
construction phasing tool. So we have to
start by ingesting this data from this
PDF into some type of like Excel sheet
or a CSV file that uses the activity or
phase IDs along with all the mesh IDs
from 3ds Max and of course with the
start and end dates for the actual
project and how many frames we want that
to show in the animation. So this is a
manual process unfortunately but we can
do this completely in Unreal without
this step if needed. But here we have a
typical CSV file that has the activity
or phase ids, start end dates of the
actual construction project or that
phase of the construction project and
how many frames we want that to start
and end along with the 3ds Max ID names.
And for ids, we just use a basic prefix.
So on the first one there, we have sheet
piles 1 through 17. If all of the sheet
piles have sheet the sheet pile prefix,
it's going to grab all of them and
assign them to that phase. We also have
animation types and whether we're adding
or removing objects in that animation.
So for this we use scriptable tools
inside of Unreal and we have preset
animation types and we use a Python
script to normalize the times to the
overall length. So the date and times
that we are given those are locked in
but it's kind of arbitrary of how many
frames we might want to use for the
animation. Once all of this is locked in
we can then decide to edit it later if
the schedule changes. So we can apply
all of these to sequencer and then all
we have to do is open this back up,
change the values and then reapply it to
sequencer and everything will just fit
into place. So here's an example of this
bypassing the manual CSV. So if you were
just wanting to create one simple
section of a phase, you can select all
your objects, grab them from the
outliner, you can change animation
presets if you want. And then we just
head over to our PDF where we grab the
phase ID just to keep it everything
organized. We can paste that in. Now,
this can also be automated as well, but
this is just showing the tool if it
wasn't pulling in it automatically. We
grab the end dates and then for here we
can just leave the frames on default
just to show how this works. And then we
simply create the animation and then all
those pieces will just fall into place.
So then we can clear the scriptable
tools section. We can go on to the next
phase, grab other elements and do the
same thing. Here we can change the
animation preset if we want to. And
after all of this data is applied, we
can then go back and then edit each one
of those groups. And it's much more easy
to do this than having to go back to 3ds
Max and then reexport out a Datasmith
file. The last part about this is that
we have this all interactive via a
timeline slider. So the client can move
around in real time if we're pixel
streaming this. And here's an example of
this. All our UI elements with a
blueprint are just easily adaptable just
based on the start and end dates or how
many days the project is going on for.
We don't have to recreate a new UI for
each one. It's very quick to do. Here's
an example of the entire thing working
where we have an example of a highway.
You can open up each specific phases and
you can grab like the notes for that
section and see in real time which part
of that project would be constructed at
the certain dates. And if we need to
make a change, all we have to do is go
and edit the dates in sequencer and
reapply the update and it will just fall
into place. We also have an interactive
callout system. So this is a system if
we want to be able to specify a specific
location or a like a hot spot of an
area. This is rendered either in world
space or screen space depending on what
we need for the project. And we have a
dcc export script. So in 3ds Max or
Cinema 4D the artists can create dummy
objects for where these callouts have to
be. And then we export that to a JSON
file and then we import that via a U
data asset. So we import that into a
data table. And then for each row of the
data table, we assign a blueprint actor
per call out. We also can draw stem
lines really easily via a widget
blueprint. And that's how you do that.
It's very simple to do.
And here's an example of a construction
sequence with callouts as well where the
client can or the user can specify what
they want to see on screen at any one
time. We have multiple different camera
views and we can see the construction
working over the course of many years.
So you can scrub the timeline. You don't
have to let it play. And you can also
change what things are what elements are
showing on screen. And uh we found this
really useful when pixel streaming.
So I'll just let that play.
So similar to our callout system, we use
uh interactive charts as well. So if the
client wants to display some other type
of data. So if for instance the the
associated cost per phase of the
project, we can ingest that data and
display it as well. So this is very
similar to our callout system except
this is purely a screen space render. We
still import the data into a data table
asset via like a CSV file or we can just

the height of the bars is normalized
based on whatever the input is. And
that's how you normalize bars. We use
one bar per blueprint actor which is not

it is it was the easiest for us to set

if we created a UI material, this would
be a lot more optimized. So something we
will work on in the future, but we can
just do it with one blueprint actor. And
here's an example of the chart system.
If we have data that the client wants to

data and then just click a button to

camera is is being shown. Okay, so
Daniel already kind of touched on our
aerial data and how we import it. So
this is the process we get everything
from near map. So this is all of our
terrain data. We have just the color
maps and also data maps. Everything is
projected in global mapper and then that
goes to the dcc and then from datas
smmith to unreal. So we use AI data
layers from near mapap to capture other
components of the scene. For example, we
have on if on the right image here we
have trees, grass, asphalt and concrete
and those are packed into an RGBA image.
We found these to be the most useful
ways of being able to utilize data
inside a blend material and I'll show
you this process here. It's very simple
to do. Once we have exported the
Datasmith file from 3ds Max, we simply
load that in. We select where those
terrain file or the terrain images are
and then the terrain masks too or the
aerial masks. And once all three of
those components are added, it combines
them all in one uh level here. So this
is a real-time look at that. And the
nice part about this is when you zoom
in, it lurps between where it's not a
simple lurp, but we're basically
blending between that aerial image and
also tileable, higher resolution
elements for grass or concrete, asphalt,
dirt, whatever we want to add. This
allows us to place the camera wherever
we want and because quite often we don't
know where the camera is going to be and
we can move around and of course if it's
a road we will model the road but
sometimes there might be like a non-hero
section that's still pretty close to the
camera and if we didn't have some kind
of way of blending them we would get a
very low resolution image like this. So
this with the blend off and with the
blend on we can still maintain some of
the macro detail from the terrain the
the aerial map but we can also get some
higher fidelity as well. So if you look
at the striations in the grass and that
field there, that kind of detail we
still wanted to preserve and we used
some lurping with some other little
techniques just to blend some of the
terrain back in. So once you blend it,
it is going to change the color, but you
can color correct every element of it.
All the channels can be color corrected,
but it still maintains some of that
macro detail while giving you a higher
fidelity image. The pack data layers
look something like this. So sometimes
this is useful for either debugging
purposes or simply seeing where things
are. So on our material instance you can
simply turn this on and this is a look
at just the tree map which leads us into
the next section which is about PCG
trees. So we used to do this with a HDA
talking to Houdini to determine the tree
placement but when PCG came out with
more tools we thought we would do this
all in PCG. So we wanted to automate the
placement of trees just based on that
aerial map that we got from near mapap.
However, there's a slight problem when
you try to sample a texture using PCG.
So, if you look at the lower image, the
white section is the actual tree map
data where all the pixels are mapping to
where trees are on that map. And the
upper image is where PCG decides that,
oh yeah, you can have trees here. So
instead of using like the individual
pixels, it kind of just divides up your
texture into grids and based on the
number of white pixels from the tree map
in that specific grid. It gives you a
weight of how likely there is to be a
tree there. Well, this is very
problematic for us because we need to be
be able to specify on very large maps
where trees can go down to like the foot
because we don't want to we don't want a
tree to spawn in the middle of a road
for instance. So instead of trying to
mess around with PCG, which we probably
could have done, but we decided it was a
a bit more efficient, allowed us a lot
more control to spawn a separate Python
process using OpenCV. So this is
something that we spawn in from Unreal,
which I'll show in a moment, but it
launches a separate Python
multi-threaded process that looks at the
tree map data and then decides based on
some custom parameters where trees are
likely to be put and how close enough
together they are. and it then will give
us back data that we can import into
PCG. Again, here's an example of this
working. We simply select the terrain
tiles that we want to use
and then we select the aerial masks that
were provided from that we grabbed from
near map and then packed. We also
specify the maximum number of trees that
we want for that entire region. And this
again is real time. You can see how long
or how slow it takes depending on how
you look at it. But this is spawning a
separate task and determining all the
tree placement. Now this is going to
create like a one giant PCG instance for
the entire terrain. Here we can add
other trees and there's a whole bunch of
other parameters that we can add in the
future once we determine what we want to
do with this data. But here is all the
points that OpenCV created. So instead
of using this in PCG, we're just giving
the points to PCG and letting it decide
where the trees go from there. So if we
zoom in, all the trees are already done.
And if we wanted to tweak the values, we
can do basic things like self-p pruning
is very simple to do inside PCG. But if
we want to completely change like the
direction of where trees are placed, we
can just nuke it and then just redo it
from the script. The other really useful
way of why we use OpenCV is that we can
then take the road masks or any other
type of masks and subtract them from the
tree mask. So quite often near mapap
would provide an image that has a tree
that's overhanging a road and it doesn't
know that that or supposed to be a road
there. So you can simply subtract
specific maps and then it's never going
to have a tree going in the middle of a
road. The other thing that we can do
with this which is not shown here. If we
realize we still want trees to be in a
specific area, we have a tool that
allows you to just draw a basic spline
and it's like an include mask. We also
do the same thing for exclude masks if
we want a specific region to not have
trees. We use PCG for other things too,
like grass and rocks. And here we have a
tool that allows us to grab the the the
outlines basically of all of the the
paths and then we can pull that back
into PCG and is only going to do grass
around those sections. So we don't have
to manually draw out splines. Very last
part about aerials is if we're color
correcting aerials or we're doing any
type of color correction or any type of
uh instance transfer, it's not a really
good way to do that inside Unreal by
default. And if you're color correcting
terrain, you're going to want it to
apply to all the other tiles. So instead
of using a material parameter
collection, which are a little bit more
cumbersome to use and don't allow you
the full data set, we decided to just
make a really quick Python utility to
select an instance then select all the
other instances that you want to
transfer your parameters to and it will
do that very quickly. So you can see all
of the terrain is now color corrected
based on that one tile that we had
selected. Okay, so this leads us into
materials and post-processes.
We have uh this is going to be probably
the largest section of this talk and
there's a kind of a lot to cover so I'll
try do my best to get through it all. We
wanted to or our mindset going into this
was we wanted something that's very fast
and artistfriendly but we also wanted to
encourage quality and performance. So
for us robustness wins over performance
most of the time because most of the
things that we're doing are just
rendering frames or we're pixel
streaming and we can handle more complex
materials. We also wanted to have a
flexible workflow. A lot of the artists
that are working on our team don't ever
need to use Unreal. We just need assets
that they give us. Those artists want to
work completely in 3ds Max and do all
their material assignments in Max. And
then someone like myself would prefer to
just do everything in Unreal. So we
wanted to have two different types of
workflows and support both. So for this
we use the connector library. Connector
is just an asset manager that allows us
to sync our materials between Max and
Unreal. So we have the same materials on
both Max and for Unreal. This is a
unified location on Perforce as well.
This keeps things really convenient.
Also allows us to curate all of our
materials and other assets. And like I
said, it syncs between Max and Unreal.
This also improves our custom Datasmith
import process, which is the next
section. If you're not aware, Datasmith
is a plug-in for transferring data to
from 3ds Max and Cinema 4D and other CAD
tools to Unreal Engine. However, there's
some problems with the default version
that we needed to extend. So, some so we
have extended functionality in the form
of some export scripts from the dcc and
a custom import script when reimpporting
a Datasmith file in Unreal Engine. This
allows the artists to choose their
workflow preferences.
And uh how our custom Datasmith works
basically um instead of allowing
Datasmith to handle all the material
creation. If an if a material is found
with the same name that exists on the
Unreal side of the connector library,
instead of having to remake the
material, it simply grabs the already
made Unreal asset and just swaps it out.
So we don't have to waste time waiting
for it to build materials. But if that
material does not exist, we have a
separate export script from the dcc that
allows a or it writes a JSON file and if
it's in the same folder as the the U
datasmith file, it will read that first.
We will create those materials that
don't exist in connector and then we it
still allows the artist to make a custom
change. The other thing that our uh
extension allows us to do is keep track
of assignments in a better way. So
instead of having random ids for the
mesh and material connections, we
actually use the material slot names
from uh the well we use the material
slot names from the multi-ub object ids
in 3ds max. This is a better way of
keeping track of assignments. So when we
reimpport the datasmith file, it quickly
does a query to make sure that the
incoming change will work with the
meshes that we have already. So for
instance, you could have two different
buildings, but then you decide in max
you want to connect them. So that it's
just one mesh. Now that would break
Datasmith and you'd have to reapply all
your materials again. Our method allows
you to keep track of both and it will
just merge them together and maintain
those material connections. The last
thing that our custom Datasmith allows
us to do is assign an object ID on each
static mesh coming in. And this is
really useful for later on when I show
some of the randomization.
So for example, this is a project in 3ds
Max. I wanted to grab a rust material
for the top section of the bridge. So I
go to connector. I just search for a
rust material, drag that into 3ds Max.
And here you can see the multisub ids
for the the materials here. And then
when we import that into Unreal Engine,
it simply finds the Unreal version of
that rust asset.
Okay. So we want everything to be robust
and performant if possible. We do have,
you know, the preference that the
material is going to be as robust as
possible. So you don't have to go back
to unre to uh the dcc. But we also want
to try to limit our instructions because
that can be a kind of a problem if you
just go crazy with it. So for speed, we
want to reduce the back and forth
between DCC, the DCC and Unreal. We
don't really have any time for
handcrafted textures and we want
wherever possible to match the
functionality of the DCC. So for
instance, the image on the right, the
top image, this is an aerial map. In 3ds
Max, it's very easy just to simply grab
the channel of the color and just plug
it into roughness. And we didn't have
that ability to do that in Unreal by
default. And we never want the artist to
ever have to go into the material graph.
And in fact, we we don't want them to
ever touch it. Right? So our some some
useful features that our material has is
that base color can drive emissive
roughness and normal channels. And this
also includes options for downstream
color correction, too. So for instance,
if you needed to change the contrast of
your aerial, it's going to allow you, if
you want to, to use that same version to
plug into roughness. So this is part of
our flexible options. Everything coming
into Unreal from our connector library
is packed. So we use AO, we use uh
roughness, height, and metallic. And we
want to make sure that if you don't need
or you don't have an AO or you don't
have a height or metal map that you can
simply just ignore it and just say no,
let's just turn on use roughness only
and just use my roughness map. I don't
want to have to waste time packing
something where all the other channels
are just blank. We also do allow full
non-packed options as well. So if you
are trying to figure out if one specific
channel is working, instead of having to
repack it every single time just to test
it, you can open it up and then you can
just put in the individual maps. Now
this is obviously not performant and we
discourage it. But if this is found to
be a problem, we can just disable the
entire thing on our master material and
uh we can just disable the functionality
completely. But it's very useful for dev
purposes. So we do have the mindset that
uh if we can fix it in UE do that. So we
do still have problems with data uh
datasmith and especially cineware which
if you have never used Cinema 4D we
